Summary: The proposal seeks to integrate biologically inspired dynamic gating mechanisms (predictive coding, dopamine-modulated reinforcement, and spiking neural networks) into a hybrid SNN-Transformer model to better replicate human attentional flexibility. It includes a detailed validation plan involving synthetic tasks, fMRI alignment, and ablation studies.
Strengths: Ambitious and novel hypothesis integrating multiple biologically inspired mechanisms.
Clear problem statement highlighting limitations of current models.
Detailed and rigorous validation plan with multiple experiments.
Potential to bridge computational models and cognitive neuroscience.
Weaknesses: Feasibility concerns, particularly in aligning model activations with fMRI and primate data.
Lacks discussion of technical challenges (e.g., computational complexity of SNNs, interpretability of hybrid models).
Overly optimistic execution plan given the complexity of the proposed model.
Limited discussion of potential pitfalls or alternative approaches.
Questions: How will the computational complexity of the hybrid SNN-Transformer model be managed?
What are the specific challenges in aligning model activations with fMRI data, and how will they be addressed?
Are there any preliminary results or pilot studies supporting the feasibility of the proposed integration?
How will the interpretability of the hybrid model be ensured, given the complexity of the proposed mechanisms?
Limitations: High computational complexity may limit scalability.
Alignment of model activations with neural data may be challenging and require significant preprocessing.
The proposed model may be difficult to interpret due to its hybrid nature.
Potential overfitting in aligning model activations with specific neural recordings.
